Member Function Documentation

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::addReference (    )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

<p> Add one to the intrinsic reference count in the underlying object.

Object in <code>SIDL</code> have an intrinsic reference count. Objects continue to exist as long as the reference count is positive. Clients should call this method whenever they create another ongoing reference to an object or interface. </p> <p> This does not have a return value because there is no language independent type that can refer to an interface or a class. </p>

Definition at line 59 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

Referenced by LocalMeshQuery.

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::deleteReference (    )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Decrease by one the intrinsic reference count in the underlying object, and delete the object if the reference is non-positive.

Objects in <code>SIDL</code> have an intrinsic reference count. Clients should call this method whenever they remove a reference to an object or interface.

Definition at line 117 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

SIDL::BaseInterface TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::queryInterface (  const::std::string &    name )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Check whether the object can support the specified interface or class.

If the <code>SIDL</code> type name in <code>name</code> is supported, then a reference to that object is returned with the reference count incremented. The callee will be responsible for calling <code>deleteReference</code> on the returned object. If the specified type is not supported, then a null reference is returned.

bool TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::isInstanceOf (  const::std::string &    name )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Return whether this object is an instance of the specified type.

The string name must be the <code>SIDL</code> type name. This routine will return <code>true</code> if and only if a cast to the string type name would succeed.

Definition at line 183 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getGeometricDimension (  int32_t &    dim )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Gets the geometric dimension of the mesh.

Note that this does not necessarily equal the highest topological entity as surface meshes consisting of two-dimensional topological elements can live in three space.

Parameters:
dim  (out) the integer dimension of the mesh
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

Definition at line 215 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

int32_t TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getNumberEntityOfType (  ::TSTT::EntityType    entity_type )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Returns the number entities in the mesh of a given type.

Parameters:
entity_type  (in) the type of entity, one of VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, or CELL. If ALL_TYPES is the input, the total number of entities in the mesh is returned. If NUMBER_OF_TYPES is the input, an error is returned.
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

Definition at line 256 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

Returns the number entities in the mesh of a given topology.

Parameters:
entity_topology  (in) the topology of the entity. If ALL_TOPOLOGIES is the input, the total number of entities in the mesh is returned. If UNDEFINED is the input, an error is returned.
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getNativeStorageOrder (  ::TSTT::StorageOrder &    storage_order )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Gets the preferred storage order of arrays returned by the mesh.

One of BLOCKED (xxx...yyyy...zzzz...), INTERLEAVED (xyzxyzxyz....), or UNDETERMINED if the mesh has no preferred storage order

Parameters:
storage_order  (out) the preferred storage order of arrays in the mesh
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

Definition at line 518 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::entityGetType (  ::SIDL::array< void * >    entity_handles,
::SIDL::array< int > &    type
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Get the type of an array of entities.

The value is returned as a value from the enumerated type EntityType. Note that duplicates the functionality in Entity_GetTopologicalDimension, but allows the user to work directly with the enumerated type rather than an integer.

Parameters:
entity_handles  (in) an array of opaque entity handles
type  (inout) an integer array that upon return contains the type of the entities in the input array; one of VERTEX, EDGE, FACE or REGION.
Returns:
Error the error object; will be have a zero error code if successful, non-zero otherwise.

Definition at line 561 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::entityGetVertexCoords (  ::SIDL::array< void * >    entity_handles,
::TSTT::StorageOrder    storage_order,
::SIDL::array< double > &    coords
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Get the coordinates of an array of vertex mesh entities.

The storage order options are handled as an enumerated type because it will be faster and more typesafe to check than a string option

Parameters:
entity_handles  (in) an array of opaque entity handles for which the coordinate information is being requested
storage_order  (in) the desired order of storage, blocked or interleaved
coords  (inout) on return this double array will contain containing the vertex coordinate information in the first num_entities*dim entries
Returns:
Error the error object; will be have a zero error code if successful, non-zero otherwise.

Definition at line 606 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::entityGetAdjacencies (  ::SIDL::array< void * >    entity_handles,
::TSTT::EntityType    entityAdjacencyType,
::SIDL::array< void * > &    adjacentEntityHandles,
::SIDL::array< int > &    csr_pointer,
::SIDL::array< int > &    csr_data
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Returns the number of adjacent entities of a given type and an array of unique identifiers for the adjacent entities.

Parameters:
entity_handles  (in) an array of opaque entity handles for which you are requesting the adjacency information
entityAdjacencyType  (in) the type of desired adjacencies
adjacentEntityHandles  (inout) on return the array of opaque pointers containing the adjacent entity information
csr_pointer  (inout) on return this integer array contains the number of entities of a given type adjacent to each requestor
csr_data  (inout) on return this integer array contains the locations of the adjacent entities in the entity_handles array
Returns:
Error the error object; will be have a zero error code if successful, non-zero otherwise.

Definition at line 655 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::initializeMeshEntityIterator (  ::TSTT::EntityType    entity_type,
::TSTT::EntityTopology    entity_topology,
void *&    entity_iterator
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Initialize the entity iterator.

The entities are returned in the meshGetNextEntity function defined below. Each iterator has an entity type and topology associated with it.

Parameters:
entity_type  (in) one of the enumerated types given VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, REGION. If ALL_TYPES is the input then the mesh will return traverse all of the entities in the mesh.
entity_topology  (in) one of the enumerated entity topology types. This serves to further refine the request for mesh traversal. For example, if one would like to traverse all of the quadrilaterals then entity_type should be set to FACE and entity_topology should be set to QUADRILATERAL. If entity_type and entity_topology are incompatible an error is returned.
entity_iterator  (out) the workset iterator. This structure should keep enough state information that the function meshGetNextWorkset will be efficient. Note, it is assumed that workset_iterator keeps a pointer to its parent mesh object so that once it's created it cannot be used with multiple meshes.
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

Definition at line 721 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getNextEntity (  void *&    entity_iterator,
void *&    entity_handle
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Get the next entity handle.

Entity handles are returned until all entities of the given type and topology have been traversed.

Parameters:
entity_iterator  (inout) the entity iterator. This structure should keep enough state information that entity access provided by this function is efficient.
entity_handle  (inout) on return this contains the current entity_handle
Returns:
Error the error object; will contain a zero integer code if the call was successful, the code will be nonzero otherwise non-NULL otherwise.

Definition at line 770 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

bool TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::entityIteratorHasMore (  void *    entity_iterator )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Returns a boolean value indicating if the entity iterator has completed its traversal through the mesh.

Parameters:
entity_iterator  (in) the entity iterator
Returns:
true if the entity iterator has not completed its traversal through the mesh, false if the traversal is complete.
Exceptions:
Error  will contain a zero integer code if the call was successful, the code will be nonzero otherwise

Parameters:
entity_iterator  (in) the entity iterator to be destroyed
Exceptions:
Error  will contain a zero integer code if the call was successful, the code will be nonzero otherwise

Definition at line 847 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::initializeWorksetIterator (  ::TSTT::EntityType    entity_type,
::TSTT::EntityTopology    entity_topology,
int32_t    requested_workset_size,
void *&    workset_iterator
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Initialize the entity workset iterator.

The entities are returned in the meshGetNextWorkset function defined below. Each iterator has an entity type, topology, and preferred workset size associated with it. Note that the meshGetEntities function can be replaced with these two calls if desired.

Parameters:
entity_type  (in) one of the enumerated types given VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, REGION. If ALL_TYPES is the input then the mesh will return traverse all of the entities in the mesh.
entity_topology  (in) one of the enumerated entity topology types. This serves to further refine the request for mesh traversal. For example, if one would like to traverse all of the quadrilaterals then entity_type should be set to FACE and entity_topology should be set to QUADRILATERAL. If entity_type and entity_topology are incompatible an error is returned.
workset_size  (in) the number of entities in each workset. The entities are returned in chunks of this size until the last workset for which the actual size will be less than requested size. Note that this can be set to a default of -1 to get the entire list of entities of a particular type.
workset_iterator  (out) the workset iterator. This structure should keep enough state information that the function meshGetNextWorkset will be efficient. Note, it is assumed that workset_iterator keeps a pointer to its parent mesh object so that once it's created it cannot be used with multiple meshes.
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

Definition at line 910 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getNextWorkset (  void *&    workset_iterator,
::SIDL::array< void * > &    entity_handles
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException )
 

Iterator to get the next workset.

Workset_size entities are returned in the entity handle array until the final workset. This allows us to traverse the entities in manageable chunks and can be tuned to provide a balance between memory overhead and performance of accessing information through interfaces.

Parameters:
workset_iterator  (inout) the workset iterator. This structure should keep enough state information that entity access provided by this function is efficient. Note, it is assumed that workset_iterator keeps a pointer to its parent mesh object so that a mesh object does not need to be passed in to this function.
entity_handles  (inout) on return this array of opaque objects will contain the entity handles in the current workset
Returns:
Error the error object; will contain a zero integer code if the call was successful, the code will be nonzero otherwise non-NULL otherwise.

Definition at line 1045 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getVertexCoordinates (  ::SIDL::array< double > &    coordinates,
::TSTT::StorageOrder &    storageOrder,
const::std::string &    options
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Get the coordinates of the vertices in the mesh in an array.

Return an array of vertex coordinates that will be indexed with a global or local ID. The user may choose the storage order to be either interleaved, xyzxyzxyz storage or blocked, xxxyyyzzz storage. It is assumed that the coordinates are returned in a fixed order that will be reproduced if no mesh modifications have occurred between calls.

Parameters:
coordinates  (inout): If this array is allocated on input then the results will be copied to this array if it is big enough, otherwise the array will be resized and the coordinate information will be returned.
storage_order  (inout): If this is set to BLOCKED or INTERLEAVED on input, the TSTT mesh is required to return the coordinates using that storage order. If this argument is set to UNDETERMINED, the TSTT mesh is free to choose one method or the other and set the value of storage_order to be the chosen type.
string  (in) : a string of options reserved for future use. No options are supported at this time.
Returns:
Error the error object; the error code will be set to zero if the method was successful, nonzero otherwise
Exceptions:
Error  the error object; the error code will be set to zero if the method was successful, nonzero otherwise

Definition at line 1103 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getEntityIndicies (  ::TSTT::EntityType    entityType,
::SIDL::array< int > &    count,
::SIDL::array< int > &    index,
const::std::string &    options
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Return the indicies of the vertices that define all entities of a given type.

The index values (i.e. the global or local ID of a vertex) for entity i are given by (assuming a compressed-row format) : index[e1],...,index[e2-1] where e1=count[i], e2=count[i+1]

Parameters:
entityType  (in) one of the enumerated types VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, REGION. This is the entity type which is requesting the vertex adjacency information. If ALL_TYPES is given as input, the vertex adjacency information is returned for all entities. It is assumed that the user knows the type and topology information to expect in this case.
count  (inout): integer array to place results in. If this array is allocated on input then the results will be copied to this array if it is big enough, otherwise the array will be resized and the coordinate information will be returned.
index  (inout) : integer array to place results in. If this array is allocated on input then the results will be copied to this array if it is big enough, otherwise the array will be resized and the coordinate information will be returned.
string  (in) : a string of options reserved for future use. No options are supported at this time.
Returns:
Error the error object; the error code will be set to zero if the method was successful, nonzero otherwise
Exceptions:

Definition at line 1176 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

TSTT::Error TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::getEntityAdjacencyIndicies (  ::TSTT::EntityType    entityType,
::TSTT::EntityType    entityAdjacencyType,
::SIDL::array< int > &    count,
::SIDL::array< int > &    index,
const::std::string &    options
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Return the indicies of the vertices that define all entities of the requested adjacency type.

The index values (i.e. the global or local ID of a vertex) for entity i are given by (assuming a compressed-row format) : index[e1],...,index[e2-1] where e1=count[i], e2=count[i+1]

Parameters:
entityType  (in) one of the enumerated types VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, REGION. This is the entity type which is requesting the adjacency information. If ALL_TYPES is given as input, an error is returned.
entityAdjacencyType  (in) one of the enumerated types VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, REGION. This is the adjacent entity type for which the vertex information is requested. If ALL_TYPES is given as input, an error is returned. Note that first order adjacencies for conformal meshes are supported; second order adjacencies are not yet supported. In particular, for the following entity_requestor:adjacency_entity_requested pairs we have
REGION:VERTEX returns the corner vertices of an region

REGION:EDGE returns the edges defining the region

REGION:FACE returns the faces defining the region

FACE:VERTEX returns the corner vertices of the face

FACE:EDGE returns the edges defining the face

EDGE:VERTEX returns the endpoints of the edge

VERTEX:REGION returns the regions for which it is a corner vertex

VERTEX:FACE returns the faces for which it is a corner vertex

VERTEX:EDGE returns the edges for which it is an endpoint

EDGE:REGION returns the regions which it helps define in that its endpoints are corner vertices of the returned regions

EDGE:FACE returns the faces which it helps define in that its endpoints are the corner vertices of the returned faces

FACE:REGION returns the elements which it helps define in that its corner vertices are the corner vertices of the returned elements

Parameters:
count  (inout): integer array to place results in. If this array is allocated on input then the results will be copied to this array if it is big enough, otherwise the array will be resized and the coordinate information will be returned.
index  (input) : integer array to place results in. If this array is allocated on input then the results will be copied to this array if it is big enough, otherwise the array will be resized and the coordinate information will be returned.
string  (in) : a string of options reserved for future use. No options are supported at this time.
Returns:
Error the error object; the error code will be set to zero if the method was successful, nonzero otherwise
Exceptions:
Error  the error object; the error code will be set to zero if the method was successful, nonzero otherwise

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::entityGetTag (  ::SIDL::array< void * >    entity_handles,

Allows the user to retrieve the an array of tag values associated with a tag handle from an array of entities.

If the entity does not have a tag handle of the approriate type, a NULL value is returned in that entry of the tag_value array.

Parameters:

tag_handle  (in) the tag handle for which to retrieve the data
tag_value  (out) the opaque values containing the tag data. The tag_data array will be returned in the same order as the entity_handles array so that the data correspondence is clear (for example, the data for entity_handle[3] is in tag_value[3]). If an entity doesn't contain a tag with the specified tag_handle, a NULL value is returned in that entry of the tag_value array and a warning message is returned in the Error object
Exceptions:

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::entitySetTag (  ::SIDL::array< void * >    entity_handles,
void *    tag_handle,

int32_t    tag_size
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Parameters:

tag_handle  (in) the tag handle for which to set the data. Note that it is assumed that the tag handle has already been created with a call to Entity_AddTag.
tag_values  (in) the opaque values containing the tag data. It is assumed that the tag_data is in the same order as the entity_handles array. Thus, for example, the data contained in tag_value[3] will be assigned to the entity associated with entity_handles[3]. Assume the tag_value array contains N entries and the entity handles array contains M entries.
If M=N All entities associated with the entity_handles array will recieve a tag_value. If N!=M an error is returned
Parameters:
tag_size  (in) the size of the data to be associated with the tag handle. Is is assumed that all data is of the same size.
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::load (  const::std::string &    name )  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Load information into a TSTT mesh.

This method must be called after Mesh_Create and before any other methods can be called to access mesh or entity information. Note that multiple Mesh_Load calls can be made for a given mesh interface. It is assumed that the union of information from each load call will be available in Mesh_Handle in the other TSTT methods.

Parameters:
name  (in) a string identifier for which mesh to load, for example from a file.
Exceptions:
Error  will contain a zero integer code if the call was successful, the code will be nonzero otherwise

Definition at line 1949 of file TSTT_LocalMeshQuery.cc.

void TSTT::LocalMeshQuery::meshGetAdjacencies (  ::TSTT::EntityType    entity_type_requestor,
::TSTT::EntityType    entity_type_requested,
::SIDL::array< void * > &    entity_handles,
::SIDL::array< int > &    count,
::SIDL::array< int > &    index
)  throw ( ::SIDL::NullIORException, ::TSTT::Error )
 

Get the adjacenty list for all of the entities of the TSTT Mesh.

The entities are returned in the form of an array of EntityHandles which uniquely identify each mesh entity of a given type. We return the data in compressed sparse row (CSR) format. In this format three arrays are returned:

index: an integer array giving the location in the index array beginning each entity's adjacency list. For example, the starting point of the adjacencies for entity k (as given in csr_adjacencies array) is given by csr_index[k], and the number of adjacencies is given by csr_index[k+1]-csr_index[k]. count: an integer array giving the locations of the adjacent entities in the entity_handles array entity_handles: the array containing unique identifiers for the requested adjacent entities

That is, the index values (i.e. the global or local ID of a vertex) for entity i are given by index[e1],...,index[e2-1] where e1=count[i], e2=count[i+1]

For example to request the vertex adjacency information of two triangles and a quadrilateral (the two triangles share vertices 1 and 2, the quadrilateral shares vertices 2 and 3 whith the second triangle) The count array is 0, 3, 6, 10 The index array is 0 1 2 1 2 3 2 3 4 5 The entity_handles array contains 6 elements uniquely identifying the vertices of the elements

Parameters:
entity_requestor  (in) the type of entity making the adjacency request; one of VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, or REGION If ALL_TYPES or NUMBER_OF_TYPES is the input, an error is returned.
adjacency_entity_requested  (in) the entity type requested; one of VERTEX, EDGE, FACE, or REGION
entity_handles  (out) the array of unique entity handles for the requested adjacencies
count  (out) an integer array that gives the number of entities adjacent to each requestor. The TSTT mesh is required to allocate this array.
index  (out) an integer array giving the locations of the adjacent entities in the entity_handles array. The TSTT mesh is required to allocate this array.
Exceptions:
Error  will have a zero error code if successful; non-zero otherwise
The following rules apply for the return values of this function.

First order (upward or downward) adjacencies are supported. We assume that mesh is conformal, adjacencies for non conformal meshes are not supported at this time.

Second order adjacencies (neighbor), although well defined, are not supported at this time and this function will return an error.

In particular, for the following entity_requestor:adjacency_entity_requested pairs we have

REGION:VERTEX returns the corner vertices of an region

REGION:EDGE returns the edges defining the region

REGION:FACE returns the faces defining the region

FACE:VERTEX returns the corner vertices of the face

FACE:EDGE returns the edges defining the face

EDGE:VERTEX returns the endpoints of the edge

VERTEX:REGION returns the regions for which it is a corner vertex

VERTEX:FACE returns the faces for which it is a corner vertex

VERTEX:EDGE returns the edges for which it is an endpoint

EDGE:REGION returns the regions which it helps define in that its endpoints are corner vertices of the returned regions

EDGE:FACE returns the faces which it helps define in that its endpoints are the corner vertices of the returned faces

FACE:REGION returns the elements which it helps define in that its corner vertices are the corner vertices of the returned elements
